newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Coast Guard helicopter crashes off Calif. coast.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Coast Guard helicopter crashes off Calif. coast.

text.p: A Coast Guard helicopter with four crew members crashed in rough seas during a rescue mission off the northern California coast, officials said on Monday.
The helicopter went down late Sunday night after responding to a distress call from a Canadian vessel 57 miles west of Cape Mendocino, about 200 miles north of San Francisco, the Coast Guard said.
Search teams Monday found the tail section of the helicopter but did not locate the crew members, a Coast Guard spokeswoman said.
"It's an intensive search. We're hoping for the best," Coast Guard spokeswoman Shannon Knight said.
The missing helicopter was last heard from at 11:25 p.m. PDT Sunday (2:25 a.m. Monday EDT). At the time, the seas were very rough, with waves 26 feet high and winds gusting from 35 to 55 knots.
"It was nasty as hell," Coast Guard spokesman Bruce Pimental said. "That's rough weather."
Coast Guard cutters, rescue helicopters and a plane were used in the search. Other rescue vessels were expected to join them Tuesday.
The Coast Guard said rescue helicopters will search after dark using night vision equipment.

The four missing helicopter crew members were identified as: Lt. Jeffery Crane from Massachusetts, Lt. Charles Thigpen from California, Petty Officer Richard Hughes from Arizona and Petty Officer James Caines from Georgia.

The five crew members aboard the Canadian sail boat, the Ezra II, were rescued and were in good condition, the Coast Guard said. Their 37-foot-long boat, travelling from Vancouver to San Francisco, was disabled when it lost its rudder. They were forced to abandon ship and were rescued from a raft.
The crew members rescued from the Canadian vessel were: Nigel Rennie of Britain, William Logan of Canada, Larry Murrell of Canada, Shirley Minion of Canada, and Murray Tildesley of the United States.
